Plotting data in Julia

Part three of this three-part series of Julia posts, in which I try to figure out how to draw some nice plots
Julia
Data Visualisation
Author

Danielle Navarro

Published

March 3, 2024

Using the Plots package

using PalmerPenguins
using Plots
using StatsPlots

Load penguins data: initially importat as CSV.file, then converted to DataFrame

penguins = DataFrame(PalmerPenguins.load())

I’ll start with scatter plot. I could use scatter() here to avoid needing to set the seriestype explicitly, but for learning purposes I find it a little easier to work with plot() for everything and control plot type via explicit attribute values:

plot(
  penguins.bill_length_mm, 
  penguins.bill_depth_mm, 
  seriestype=:scatter
)

It’s little awkward to refer to the penguins data frame repeatedly in this code, and so it’s more convenient to use the @df macro:

@df penguins plot(
  :bill_length_mm,
  :bill_depth_mm,
  seriestype=:scatter,
  group=:species
)

Adding labels is achieved by modifying the relevant attributes:

@df penguins plot(
  :bill_length_mm,
  :bill_depth_mm,
  seriestype=:scatter,
  group=:species,
  title="Palmer Penguins",
  xlabel="Bill Length (mm)",
  ylabel="Bill Depth (mm)"
)

Filter rows that have missing bill lengths, because violin series can’t handle missing values. first let’s find the the rows we want to keep:

keep = .!ismissing.(penguins.bill_length_mm)

So now this data frame is violin safe…

bill_lengths = penguins[keep, [:bill_length_mm, :species]]

So now we can create a violin plot

@df bill_lengths plot(
    string.(:species),
    :bill_length_mm,
    seriestype=:violin,
    legend=false,
    xlabel="Species",
    ylabel="Bill Length (mm)"
)
